newsitem.title: USA: Lilly says Prozac sales up despite pressure.
newsitem.headline: Lilly says Prozac sales up despite pressure.

text.p: Eli Lilly and Co said sales of the blockbuster antidepressant Prozac rose 13 percent in the first nine months of 1996 over the year-ago period.

For the first nine months of 1996, worldwide sales of Prozac were $1.753 billion, up from $1.551 billion in the year-ago period, the drugmaker said. Sales of the drug were up 10 percent in the third quarter over year-ago levels. Quarterly sales figures were not immediately available.
Lilly said Prozac's gains were made "despite continuing competition from generic forms of Prozac in Canada and substantial competitive pressures in France."

Sales of the human insulin Humulin increased 15 percent for the quarter, Lilly said. For the first nine months of 1996, worldwide sales of Humulin were $645 million, an increase of 11 percent compared with $582 million in the same period of 1995.
ReoPro, a blood clot breaking drug, "continued to show very steady sales growth," Lilly said. For the first nine months of 1996, worldwide sales of ReoPro were $98 million.
Sales of the ulcer medication Axid in the first nine months of 1996 were $394 million, compared with $399 million a year ago.
Sales in the first nine months of the antibiotic Ceclor/ceflacor were $385 million, compared with $539 million a year ago, Lilly said.
Worldwide sales of animal health products increased two percent compared with the third quarter of 1995, it said.
Worldwide sales for the quarter were $1.804 billion, an increase of 11 percent compared with sales of $1.632 billion in the third quarter of 1995.
Sales growth was led by Prozac, Humulin and two of the company's newer products, Gemzar and ReoPro, Lilly said.
"In addition, the quarter benefited from increased health care management revenues, primarily PCS. Revenue growth was partially offset by lower sales of anti-infectives," Lilly said.

Manufacturing costs as a percent of sales for the quarter were higher due primarily to a sales mix that included increased revenues from lower margin lines, such as ReoPro and health care management services, the company said.
Marketing and administrative expenses rose seven percent from the third quarter of 1995 partially due to the new product launches of Gemzar and Humalog, Lilly said.
Also adding to higher expenses were the anticipated launches of Zyprexa and the cost of reserves taken to cover outstanding receivables from FoxMeyer Health Corp.

"Increased information technology capabilities and continued globalization of the company's products, particularly in emerging markets, also contributed to the increase in marketing and administrative expenses," Lilly said.
